title: The last thing we need at this point is a second referendum
text:
You could argue the problem began in 2008 – or perhaps earlier, in 2005.

Fifteen years ago, Europe’s member states were in the process of gathering together the loose threads of the two foundational texts of the European Union: the 1957 Treaty of Rome and the Maastricht Treaty of 1992, the latter having already come close to rending the Tory Party asunder.

By then, what had begun as a tidying-up exercise had morphed into the creation of a European constitution, the first stage in what some feared and others hoped would become a full-blown European super-state.

What followed would lead inexorably to the 2016 EU referendum, and the current tortures over Brexit: a country divided, a future uncertain...
